purpose_overview.goal: Achieve fat loss while preserving lean muscle mass and maintaining training performance.
purpose_overview.approach: Create a moderate caloric deficit (15–25% below maintenance) with nutrient-dense whole foods.
purpose_overview.best_for: Beginner to advanced lifters, recreational athletes, general population looking for sustainable fat loss.
purpose_overview.why_it_works: By combining a moderate deficit with sufficient protein and resistance training, fat loss is maximized while minimizing muscle loss (Hall & Guo, Gastroenterology, 2017).

caloric_strategy.maintenance_calculation: Estimate TDEE with Mifflin-St Jeor or Cunningham equation.
caloric_strategy.target_weight_loss: 0.5–1.0% body weight per week (e.g., 0.4–0.8 kg for an 80 kg person).
caloric_strategy.adjustment_tip: If fat loss stalls >2 weeks, reduce intake by additional 150–250 kcal/day or increase activity.

rationale.protein: Preserves lean mass during caloric deficit (Morton et al., 2018).
rationale.carbohydrates: Fuels resistance and endurance training, preserves performance.
rationale.fiber: Enhances satiety, digestion, and gut health.

meal_timing_distribution.protein_distribution: 20–40 g per meal, spaced every ~3–4 hr for consistent muscle protein synthesis.
meal_timing_distribution.pre_workout: 2–3 hr before: Complex carbs + lean protein (e.g., chicken + rice + vegetables).
meal_timing_distribution.post_workout: Within 2 hr: 20–40 g protein + 0.8–1.2 g/kg carbs.
meal_timing_distribution.hydration: 35–45 ml/kg/day water; add electrolytes if sweating heavily.

supplements_optional: Creatine Monohydrate (3–5 g/day) – Supports strength and preserves lean mass in a deficit.
Whey/Plant Protein – Convenient to hit protein targets.
Caffeine (3–6 mg/kg pre-workout) – Boosts training intensity and fat oxidation.
Vitamin D & Omega-3 – Beneficial for health, mood, and recovery.
Multivitamin (basic) – Helps cover potential micronutrient gaps.

monitoring_adjustments.body_weight: Weekly average – If weight loss <0.5%/week for 2+ weeks, reduce calories by 150–250/day.
monitoring_adjustments.strength_progress: Weekly – If strength drops significantly, increase carbs slightly or adjust deficit.
monitoring_adjustments.body_composition: Every 4–6 weeks – Photos, BIA, or skinfolds for fat/muscle tracking.

advantages: Preserves lean muscle while cutting fat.
Fits well with resistance and endurance training.
limitations: Slower results compared to aggressive crash diets.
Requires consistency and some tracking at least initially.
Some individuals may prefer stricter structures (keto, IF, etc.) for adherence.
scientific_references: Morton RW et al. (2018). Protein supplementation on resistance training-induced gains in muscle mass and strength. Br J Sports Med, 52(6):376–384.
Hall KD & Guo J (2017). Obesity energetics: body weight regulation and the effects of diet composition. Gastroenterology, 152(7):1718–1727.
Kerksick CM et al. (2017). ISSN position stand: nutrient timing. J Int Soc Sports Nutr, 14:33.
American College of Sports Medicine (2022). Nutrition and Athletic Performance Position Stand.
